Hi,
	I think we probably understand each other.  I was trying to point out that 
to me, "made a decision" was a bit strong for what I thought the lemurs 
were doing.  Obviously "decision" is a vague term and covers a range of things:

- simple mechanical effects, such as "impacts with outer balls decided 
which pocket the cue ball would land in

- information theory "choices" such as "the algorithm decides on a set of 
values which..."

- GAP

- conscious choices where some entity is aware of the choice

And in the GAP we have a whole range of other distinctions which don't 
usually come up, but which we are getting into here:

- complex but inflexible behaviour (e.g. Sphex)

- unconscious decisions (where a lot of processing has gone on but nothing 
ever separated out a single choice and labelled it as such -- example, 
unconsciously avoiding furniture whilst crossing a room)

- learned exact mimicry (e.g. where an entity does what it was trained 
without a question of doing otherwise)

- learned variable behaviour (e.g. the lemur, the sequence is variable but 
personally I don't think the lemur has the choice of not matching it, it 
was trained to match it)

- "intelligent" decisions where some entity is has internal structures 
representing the choice and could be queried as to what choice it was 
making (awkward phrasing here to avoid using the loaded word "aware" -- 
e.g. we have no proven examples but an intelligent but non-conscious AI 
would be categorized here)

- conscious choices using learned reasoning (e.g. applying known maths 
techniques)

- conscious choices involving ad hoc reasoning (e.g. when you meet a 
logical but previously unknown problem)

So what I was trying to do was distinguish between "learned variable 
behaviour" which is where I think the lemurs are, and any of the "higher" 
definitions, such as "conscious choice using learned reasoning".

To put it another way, the lemur has been "trained" to repeat the sequence, 
it did not "learn" to repeat the sequence.  The difference being that the 
latter comes with understanding of what one is doing (understanding which 
could, for example, be used to adapt the ability to types of sequence).

Experiments of this sort have to be treated very carefully.  They only as 
demonstrate the thing they were designed to demonstrate.  This one 
demonstrates short-term sequence memory.  That is the one component that 
the lemur could not perform without.  It is tempting to try to draw further 
conclusions about how the lemur's mind works or how it learns or what 
exactly it is doing (I'm not saying you were), but history is dotted with 
cases where folk did that and came unstuck.  Animals are very complex 
systems which do sophisticated things.  And we are programmed to interpret 
detailed mind-state information from the actions of other humans.  Its very 
very easy to unconsciously apply that interpretation to animals and assume 
that they are achieving things the same way we do.  Whereas in fact the 
history of such studies has generally been about discovering that they do 
not.  e.g. chimps and sign language, or even Clever Hans.

-

Anyway, to get back to the interesting stuff.  Do you think that sequence 
memory is achieved by having a central "sequencer" which temporarily wires 
its "first, second, third" outputs to the sub-nets for the concepts in the 
sequence?  Or would you think that different types of sequence are 
processed in different ways?  I know that when I learn music it feels very 
different from memorizing (say) a phone number.

	Ian B
